This paper was prepared for a project on Social Development in East Asia. The project was organized by the World Bank Institute under the auspices of the Program for the Study of the Japanese Development Management Experience (The Brain Trust Program), which is financed by the Policy and Human Resources Development Trust Fund established at the World Bank by the Government of Japan (GOJ). We greatly appreciate the generous support from GOJ.
The principal objectives of this Program are to conduct studies on Japanese and East Asian development management experience and to share the lessons of this experience with developing and transition economies. The experiences of other countries are often covered in order to ensure that these lessons are placed in the proper context. This comparative method helps identify factors that influence the effectiveness of specific institutional mechanisms, governance structures, and policy reforms in different contexts. A related objective of the Program is to promote the exchange of ideas on development among Japanese and non-Japanese scholars, technical experts and policy makers.
The papers commissioned for this project cover a number of important issues related to Japanese Social Policy. These issues include, among other, Japanese pension system, public health insurance in Japan, evolution of social policy in Japan, role of families, communities and government in improving socioeconomic performance, and Japanese policies towards poverty & public assistance. We hope that these papers will provide important policy findings and lessons for policymakers in developing countries and other development stakeholders.

The Role of Families, Communities, and Governments in Improving Socioeconomic Performance: The Japanese Experience
Shinji Yamashige
Department of Economics Hitotsubashi University
Abstract
By tracing Japan's history, we argue that families and communities have played important roles in the country's successful socieconomic performance. The argument is first made by comparing Japan's socioeconomic data with those of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries. Then, we look into some case studies to gain a better understanding of the roles played by Japanese families and communities. This argument does not imply, however, that government had a small role; on the contrary, the Japanese government succeeded in attaining high socioeconomic levels at relatively low cost by supporting and utilizing families and communities (which may be termed a Japanese-style welfare policy). Finally we argue that along with economic growth in Japan, family and community ties have weakened to a point at which the government must assume larger roles to maintain socioeconomic performance.
Introduction
In 1990's Human Development Report by the United Nations (UNDP 1990), Japan was given the highest human development ranking based on: (a) life expectancy, (b) literacy ratio, and (c) gross national product (GNP) per capita. (See table 1.) Although it is not easy to construct a measure for socioeconomic performance, there is no doubt that these indexes are important elements of any such measure. The table also lists in its fifth column the number of homicides per 100,000 people, which suggests that Japan also performs well in terms of a safe social environment.1 It is natural to wonder how Japan has attained such high levels of social performance. Needless to say, high economic performance represented by per capita GNP is an important factor. It is not, however, a sufficient (or necessary) condition for high social performance. For instance, some oil- producing high-income countries (for example, United Arab Emirates and Kuwait) do not perform well socially, and some low-income countries (for example, Spain and Ireland) are ranked as countries with high social performance. Furthermore, as table 2 shows, Japan had already attained high socioeconomic

Given such facts, a standard explanation may be that government policies are important factors in high social performance. By looking at the per capita social expenditure (in Purchasing Power Pairty or PPP U.S. dollars) in the fourth data column of tables 1 and 2, however, we recognize that Japan has one of the lowest figures among developed countries.2 So the question before us is: Why has Japan attained this level with such a low per capita social expenditure? In this paper we argue that families and communities have played important roles in Japan's social development performance. This, however, does not mean the government's role has been minimal; rather, we claim that the government succeeded in attaining high socioeconomic levels (with relatively low costs) by capitalizing on the strong ties typifying families and communities in Japan. Then, we argue that these family and community ties have been weakening to a point at which the government must take on a larger role in the future to maintain socioeconomic performance.

The paper is organized in seven sections including this introduction. In the next section, we provide a conceptual framework developed in Yamashige (1995), which tries to clarify the relationship among families, communities, markets, and governments. We also show, as a preliminary, that social expenditures have indeed been small in Japan even if we take the effects of the elderly ratio into account. In the two subsequent sections we examine families and communities in Japan, respectively, to show that their strengths feed Japan's socioeconomic success. In the fifth section, by examining the history of social policies and the ideology of the "Japanese-style welfare society" in Japan, we argue that the strength of families and communities has been purposely maintained and used by the Japanese government. Then, in the sixth section, we turn to the present and future of Japanese society to show that the government is now required to take on a more active role in maintaining the socioeconomic situation because families and communities have lost their strength. Concluding remarks are in the final section.
A Conceptual Framework
The first objective of this section is to provide a conceptual framework as a theoretical basis of our analysis of the roles of families and communities in Japan. The second objective is to show that the  4 Shinji Yamashige
government expenditure on socioeconomic development has indeed been small, which is an empirical basis for our claim that it is families and communities in Japan, not the government, that have played important roles in improving socioeconomic performance. Our well-being is dependent on various factors. We think that the following four are especially important; (a) material affluence, (b) risk-sharing (for example, receiving care when sick or bedridden), (c) a positive social environment (for example, a safe living environment), and (d) a livable natural environment (for example, clean air and water). In this paper, we refer to the success in attaining material affluence as economic performance, and to the success in improving risk-sharing, social environment, and natural environment as social performance. The quality of our lives is determined by both economic and social performance. In order to improve their quality of life, societies have developed and used social institutions such as families, communities, markets, and governments. Markets have helped us use our resources efficiently and thus reach material affluence. They also help us insure ourselves against risks. However, markets do not guarantee material affluence for everyone; some people will suffer under a purely market-driven system, which can be seen as a failure of insurance against the risks of being born poor. Furthermore, markets cannot fully insure risks in general, owing to moral hazard and adverse selection problems. In essence, markets do not necessarily improve our social environment--or protect our natural environment, either, for that matter. In short, markets are not almighty. In fact, historically speaking, they have not been the main institution that would be expected to maintain the quality of our lives (see, for example, Malinowski (1922)). Families and communities have played important roles in improving social performance by protecting the lives of unfortunate individuals, by sharing various risks, and by solving the problems related to externalities to improve social and natural environments. They also have helped improve economic performance by non-anonymous exchanges of goods and services (even though the ability of this measure to bring together potential traders and thus improve economic efficiency is far inferior to anonymous trading in markets). Now, in many so-called welfare states, governments have taken over the roles of families and communities in improving social performance (for example, see Coleman (1990)). In the hypothesis, a family is identified as a special case of a community because socioeconomic roles and the mechanism to implement them are not so different between the two cases. Namely, by a community we envision an institution whose goal is to improve the welfare of its members; a family is a special case of this, and conversely, communities are somewhat perceived as extended families. There are three causal relations in the diagram. Based on these we will outline three hypotheses:
(H1) As the market system expands in a society, more goods and services (including insurance) become available, and thus each individual loses reasons for remaining a community member. Furthermore, when everything is available in markets, social punishments unleashed by  The Role of Families, Communities, and Governments in Improving Socioeconomic Performance 5
communities (for example, ostracism) are no longer effective in inducing cooperation for improving social performance; (H2) As community ties weaken, they have a harder time maintaining social performance and thus people come to demand that government play the roles that communities had shouldered up to that point; and (H3) As the government's role as a substitute grows, communities become weaker.
According to our hypothesis, before a market system prevailed, communities played roles that governments are now playing. In this scenario, society can attain a high level of social performance with low government expenditure. As the market system infiltrates society and the economy grows, community ties weaken as mentioned earlier and government expenditure also grows in order to maintain social performance. Needless to say, good social performance will help increase material affluence (in other words, economic performance) by, for example, making quality health care, good education, and trust among people possible (compare Fukuyama (1995)). Thus, understanding social mechanisms to improve social performance is quite important in evaluating development strategies in many countries. In the following sections, we show that this conceptual framework is useful for understanding Japan's socioeconomic history and the roles of family and community institutions.

Accepting that the social expenditure of the Japanese government has been small, the fact that the people have been successful socioeconomically looks puzzling. As we have already suggested, however, the picture becomes clearer once we recognize the roles played by families and communities in Japan. In the next two sections, we try to show that families and communities were strong in Japan in the past, and we try to find out how they helped the population improve socioeconomically. Our discussion should show that families mainly acted as units of risk-sharing, and communities made great efforts to improve and maintain the social environment.5
Family Ties in Japan
In this section, first we show that families in Japan have strong ties compared with those in other developed countries, and that they have played important roles in improving risk-sharing and maintaining the social environment. Then we argue that these roles have been sustained by a social norm dictating that women should take care of the home.
The Strength of Families: An International Comparison
We start by looking into whether family ties are really strong in Japan. Although it is not an easy indicator to quantify, let us first look at average household sizes and divorce rates in table 3, which is based on United Nations (1987, 1991). We think that household size is a reliable measure for determining family strength because a large household enables a family to carry risk-sharing roles efficiently (as the law of larger numbers suggests). Divorce rates also reflect this strength because the longer contract terms are (as the theory of repeated games suggests) the greater the likelihood of cooperation among family members to improve the social environment. The table shows that Japan is third (behind Ireland and Spain) in average household size and is also third (behind Spain and Italy) in terms of its divorce rate among countries examined. Although the data above are suggestive, it does not provide us with a clear portrait of Japanese families, which we will explore in greater detail here. One of the characteristics of a Japanese family is that the ratio of elderly people living with their children is quite high. A study by the Prime Minister's Office (1981) summarized in table 4 shows that in Japan many old people have been living with their children (especially with their son's family), while in Western societies the elderly are more or less living independent lives. According to the 1980 census, among the elderly over 65, about 70 percent were living with their own children in Japan; and the ratio was more than 80 percent about 1960 (see also figure 13). Moreover, we would like to argue that family strength reduces government expenditure. Women's Roles in Japanese Families

It is important for us to note that wives play important roles in caring for children and the elderly. Community Ties in Japan
We showed in the previous section that families had strong ties and were instrumental in improving risk- sharing and the social environment. Families, however, are often too small to fully hedge risks and create a good social and natural environment. Therefore it is natural to expect that larger units such as communities play greater roles in improving social performance.
Neighborhood Associations as Nonprofit Organizations in Japan
Since feudal times, communities in Japan have featured strong neighborhood associations.11 In September 1940, to provide channels for transmitting government policies down to the people during the war, Home Ministry Ordinance No. 17 called for the political organization of neighborhood associations. In 1947 the general headquarters of the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers (referred to as GHQ/SCAP) abolished the ordinance and tried to ban the neighborhood associations as well because of their "undemocratic" nature. As the ordinance outlawing neighborhood associations became void in October 1952 after the San Francisco Peace Treaty, neighborhood associations reemerged out of the underground to play active roles. It is said that the government contemplated the revival of a uniform, legalized system of neighborhood associations, but it did not take any step toward this reestablishment. Nevertheless, neighborhood associations continue to be important institutions in Japan. A study by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) in 1980 (compare Isomura and Hoshino (1990)) reported that there were 274,738 neighborhood

A Case Study
We showed in the last subsection that neighborhood associations in Japan have played many roles that local governments would have played in other countries. Japanese local governments have used neighborhood associations to complement their tasks at low cost via monetary contributions and volunteer work donated by association members.16 In the following paragraphs, we want to discuss a case study (Iwasaki and others 1989) on neighborhood associations in Ueda, a mid-size city in Japan. Ueda is a third-largest city in the prefecture of Nagano. The city's population was 116,178 as of 1985. The working population is divided into manufacturing (36 percent), retail and wholesale (21 percent), services (17 percent), agriculture (9 percent), and others (17 percent). Like many cities of this size in Japan, it has experienced a shift from agriculture to manufacturing: the agricultural population dropped by 30 percent from 1965 to 1985. In Ueda, there are 156 "autonomy associations" (neighborhood associations); their membership ranges from 25 households to 1,402 households. (The average is 234). We will now summarize some basic facts about them. (1) The characteristics of the chairmen: The characteristics of the chairmen in each autonomous association are informative. First, many are chosen from a pool of elderly people. More than 65 percent of them are over 60 years old. Second, many of them (32 percent) are retired persons (of which 51 percent are retired civil servants), which is considered important in terms of their relationship with the local government. The term of a chairman is usually short; 83 percent of the terms last less than three years. About 45 percent of these chairmen are chosen by the votes of all members. The rest are chosen by indirect voting among executive members, or by recommendations from general members. (2) The inhabitants' participation: It is said that 61 percent of autonomy associations consider the participation of each household in the association to be automatic, 22 percent encourage each household to participate, and 11 percent think that participation is voluntary. In general, however, most people think that

The average inhabitants' fee is 825 yen per month and the average government subsidy (for example, for the circulation of the city newsletter and the cleaning of ditches) is 1,310 yen per year (for each average household). Autonomy associations pay donations (whose amounts are often assigned to each association in various donation campaigns--of the Red Cross, for example) by charging an amount for each household (for example, about 100 yen per month). It is said that the goals of donation campaigns are thus reached quite easily. (4) Administrative complaints: Among various complaints in the administration of autonomy associations, the following are major ones: "too many tasks are commissioned by local governments (77 percent)," "few want to be executive members (50 percent)," and "members are indifferent to and passive in community activities (36 percent)." These indicate that the tasks expected of each association are numerous and thus few people actively want to participate. (5) The association's relationship with the local government: The local government's views may be seen in its "Long-Term Visions," a document prepared by the government of Ueda. It says that "each autonomy association is a tie which connects people and the government. For this purpose, the government encourages the sense of autonomy of autonomy associations, their cooperation with the government which respects their voluntary actions, and the strength of the organizations," and that "the government recognizes that the autonomy associations are voluntary organizations, and it supports them so that they can play their roles in the communities." Data reveal that the government responds quite positively to the demands of autonomy associations (76 percent resolution rate) in addition to paying subsidies to them. Summary
The discussion above shows how communities in Japan (neighborhood associations) have helped to improve social performance.
Functions of Japanese communities are not that different from those of churches or "communities" in Western societies. A big difference is that household participation in a neighborhood association is mandatory. This prevents the free-rider problem and thus the undersupply of the voluntary provision of  18 Shinji Yamashige
public goods. Especially in big cities where socially marginal people are often neglected or tend to commit crimes aided by the anonymity there, this system of neighborhood associations seems valuable. The division of cities into smaller associations and each household's mandatory participation in one of them have prevented negligence toward those who need care and help, and also have prevented crimes, helping cities to maintain a good social environment. In short, we believe that this compulsory nature of neighborhood associations is a key element in evaluating the successful social performance of Japanese communities. In a study of communities in Japan, it is not easy to identify the effects of neighborhood associations on social performance because there are few official data on them. Hence, as proxies for community ties, we used the ratio of owned houses (ROH) and the number of consultations by welfare commissioners17 (CWC) in each prefecture and examined their relationship with the crime rate (CR). Since people would come to have long-term relationships with and thus strong ties to the community when they owned homes in great numbers, and since consultations by welfare commissioners could be seen as evidence that people trust neighbors, we expected both to have a positive impact on reducing the crime rate. The result, shown in the following equation and mapped out in figure 9, validates our assumption.

The mandatory nature of neighborhood associations, however, is also a problem. In this respect, each neighborhood association is almost like a government, but without any legal rights. Therefore some people, especially those who are accustomed to contract-based human relationships, are opposed to the existence and activities of neighborhood associations. It does not seem to be a serious problem, however, for ordinary Japanese because of the associations' long tradition--and reaction against these associations is muted because local governments are able to use them to maintain the social environment at fairly low cost.
Japanese-Style Welfare Policy
In the previous two sections, we showed that families and communities in Japan have kept relatively strong ties and played active roles in maintaining their social environment. At the same time, we suggested that the Japanese government has also played active roles in supporting families and communities in order for them to be able to play their roles--for example, by providing various tax breaks and subsidies to families and communities. Looking back at the history of government policies in Japan, we recognize that this is exactly what the Japanese government has intended to do since the Meiji era when a Western-style modern government was established after the shogunal period. For example, Garon (1997) describes the idea of the Meiji government as follows: "Tokonami TakejirÃ¿, chief of the Bureau of Local Affairs in 1910 and later an influential home minister, emphasized the role of the Japanese family. In Western countries, where `individualism' flourished, elaborate welfare programs treated members of families as individuals, but `in Japan, the family is the unit of society. A parent must raise a child, and a child must help his parent. Brothers must be kind to each other.... This has been the social organization of our country since ancient times.' The reliance on the family, asserted Tokonami, explained why there were so few poor people in Japan, despite `extremely low expenditures' on charity and relief efforts" (pp. 41Â­42). Garon (1997) also clearly recognizes that although the Japanese government did not provide relief to individuals, it is not a "laissez-faire" administration that just hopes families and communities would take care of the unfortunate: "Although the imported doctrine of laissez-faire reinforced the Meiji government's determination to avoid large expenditures on poor relief, Japanese officials categorically rejected the liberal principle that the state should play a minor role in managing the welfare of its people. Whereas liberal thinkers hoped that people would aid their unfortunate neighbors out of a sense of moral duty, the authorities did their utmost to manage the provision of relief at the local levels so that `mutual fellowship among the people' [would] become [a] reality.... `Laissez-faire' would have been the last word to describe the many instances in which the state intervened to force families and neighbors to aid the poor" (p.38). Schematically, the Japanese-style welfare policy can be illustrated as in figure 10.18 In contrast to what we call "laissez-faire policy" and "Western-style welfare policy,"19 in Japanese- style welfare policy the government plays a major role in supporting families and communities (but not individuals) in order to manage the welfare of individuals.

Although the Japanese people rarely hear the term "Japanese-style welfare society" these days, the idea remains alive in the Japanese legal system. The Japanese constitution requires the national government to assume responsibility for maintaining a minimum standard of living for the people (Article 25). The civil code of Japan, however, clearly requires that family members support each other: "The lineal relatives by blood and brothers and sisters shall be under duty to furnish support to each other.... If there are special circumstances, the Family Court may impose a duty to furnish support as between the relatives within the third degree other than those mentioned in the preceding paragraph" (Article 877).
We do not agree with this assessment. First, an objection is made only regarding the roles of communities and firms, not on the roles of families. Second, the objection toward the welfare roles of communities is based on visible contributions to charities by U.S. communities, when an important welfare role for communities in Japan is mutual and voluntary assistance among neighbors. Finally, although it may be true that as a whole similarities with the West overshadow the differences, we believe that small differences are significant because they can have a great influence on outcomes.  22 Shinji Yamashige
Furthermore, the Daily Life Security Law22 states that support by the family (defined in the civil code above) should precede any public assistance (Article 4), and that public assistance shall be determined based on, in principle, households and not individuals (Article 10). What we can see here is the fact that the idea of Japanese-style social policy has been embedded in the Japanese legal system. We can also see the same spirit, for example, in the annual report of the Ministry of Health and Welfare (1997) which is subtitled "Families and Social Security: For the Social Support of Families." The tone of the annual report, however, is different from that of the 1978 white paper above, because the report now emphasizes the transformation of Japanese families after the war to convince people of the necessity of a new social security system for Japan's aging population. As we see in the next section, families and communities are indeed changing in Japan. It may be useful, however, to point out that the new welfare system proposed is not the Western-style system, but a Japanese-style system with greater support for families and communities. It is in this sense that the idea of a "Japanese-style welfare society" lives on.

Although we do not know of any empirical work that traces the histories of a community--and thus we are unaware of any data that statistically support our claim that ties of communities are also weakening in Japan--Steiner's observations above and one of the administrative complaints in Ueda discussed in a previous subsection ["A Case Study"] both suggest a weakening of communities in Japan. The logic expressed in the above passages from Steiner (1965) is the one described in our hypothesis (H1), defined earlier, that attributes the weakening of community ties to market expansion. As noted earlier, the legal ambiguity of neighborhood associations also seems to have damaged community ties, as formal contracts prevail under the market system. As communities get weaker, we should expect more free-rider problems in Japan. Needless to say, a solution to free-rider problems is to legalize the system of neighborhood associations as a social contract among inhabitants, just as governments are legally instituted to overcome the free-rider problems in the supply of public goods. Looking back at the histories of neighborhood associations in Japan, however, it is quite doubtful whether such a reform would be accepted. Even if neighborhood associations are legalized, it is still questionable whether they can induce the compulsory participation of inhabitants, which is the key element for attaining a high level of social performance. As Steiner observed, the trend of the times is not favorable to Japanese society. Figure 14, based on Ministry of Justice (1996) shows that the crime rate represented by the number of criminal offenses (other than traffic violations) per million persons had been gradually declining in Japan after World War II but has been increasing again since the mid-1970s. Based on the discussion on the roles of families and communities in Japan and on their recent dissolution, it may not be too far off to suggest that the recent criminal trend is a consequence of the weakening of families and communities. Needless to say, we need more time and analyses to validate this view.
Concluding Remarks
After World War II, Japan enjoyed strong economic growth in a fairly short period of time. At the same time, the country maintained its social performance while keeping social expenditures at one of the lowest levels among developed countries. In this paper, we argued that by studying socioeconomic histories of Japan, one can identify strong families and communities as having played important roles in attaining high levels of social performance--exemplified by good health, quality education, and low crime rates--while keeping related expenses to a minimum. An interesting observation found in our study is that the Japanese government made active use of these social institutions to achieve maximum performance at minimum cost. Favorable taxes and social insurance to housewives, and the use of neighborhood associations as agencies seem to have been strategically designed to preserve and use Japan's strong family and community structure. Now, after rapid economic growth, Japanese society is changing. That almost anything can be purchased and sold under the market system that has prevailed allows each individual to be independent of family and community. The steady increase in the divorce rate and the decrease in household size suggest  The Role of Families, Communities, and Governments in Improving Socioeconomic Performance 25

that this is indeed the case. The expansion of the market system also has changed the social attitudes of Japanese from a norm-based one (groupism) to a contract-based one (individualism). In this respect, informal neighborhood associations, which used to provide safety nets, have also lost their importance to a great extent. Facing these social changes in Japan, the government has been seeking new ways to cope with them. Two recently passed laws can be seen as evidence that the government still tries to deal with the problem of weakening families and communities within the framework of the "Japanese-style welfare society" by providing greater support for them. First, in the new long-term care insurance system, the government has made an effort to provide more help to those who want to take care of elderly relatives at home. Compared with a policy to increase nursing homes, for example, this new system (which is a modification of the German system) would allow the government to save money. Second, under the newly revised local autonomy law, neighborhood associations can now be legal entities, which would allow them to have a more sound foundation to play their roles in their communities. Although we do not know whether these new policies will succeed in improving social welfare without increasing social expenditure, the attempts seem worthy of a follow-up study. Looking back at Japan's socioeconomic history, we are inclined to think that the utilization of traditional social systems such as families and communities can be a particularly effective strategy for steady and stable socioeconomic growth. As the failure of the GHQ/SCAP policy to abolish neighborhood associations shows, it would be nearly impossible to change the social structure in one day. Since families and communities have long been institutions that helped improve socioeconomic performance in most societies, the government's cooperation--if it is successful--with these institutions would induce positive outcomes. Thus it seems useful to design development strategies which first utilize "traditional" social systems in each country to guarantee the best possible outcome in the long run. Although nourishing families and communities may require certain government expenditures (for example, subsidies) to rekindle the mutual-help notion within them (especially when the market system expands), the Japanese experience suggests that such expenses are a good risk because they would eventually allow us to reach  26 Shinji Yamashige
the same level of social performance at a lower cost. It is our hope that our study not only sheds new light on the socioeconomic history of Japan but also provides some insights on development strategies for other countries in various stages of development.

doc.repnme: The role of families, communities, and governments in Improving socioeconomic performance : The Japanese experience
doc.abstracts: By tracing Japan's history, the paper argues that families and communities have played important roles in the country's successful socioeconomic performance. The argument is first made by comparing Japan's socioeconomic data with those of other OECD countries. Then, the paper presents some case studies to gain a better understanding of the roles played by Japanese families and communities. This does not imply, however, that government had a small role. On the contrary, the Japanese government succeeded in attaining high socioeconomic levels at relatively low cost by supporting and utilizing families & communities. This may be termed a Japanese-style welfare policy. Finally, the paper argues that along with economic growth in Japan, family and community ties have weakened to a point at which the government must assume larger roles to maintain socioeconomic performance. This paper was prepared for a project on Local Government Development in Japan. The principal objectives of this Program are to conduct studies on Japanese and East Asian development management experience and to disseminate the lessons of this experience to developing and transition economies.
